newsitem.title: ISRAEL: Israel foreign currency reform agreed -Netanyahu.
newsitem.headline: Israel foreign currency reform agreed -Netanyahu.

text.p: Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said on Tuesday an agreement had been reached with Bank of Israel Governor Jacob Frenkel and Finance Minister Dan Meridor on a foreign currency reform.

In remarks broadcast on Israel Radio he said an additional budget cut had also been agreed during a marathon all-night meeting at Caesarea. But no decision had been reached yet on the thorny issue of widening the shekel's trading band and Netanyahu said talks would continue later on Tuesday.

steps...The first of which, and the important one, is the far-reaching reform on all foreign currency matters. This matter will touch every citizen in Israel, institutional elements, businesses and citizens," Netanyahu said.
"We are going to make a great revolution that will really allow freedom in all foreign currency matters," he said.
"The second issue that we agreed was about another cut in the budget in order to achieve the deficit goal we set ourselves," Netanyahu said.
The 1997 budget already includes a reduction of seven billion shekels.
The prime minister did not specify the size of the new cut but Israel Radio reported it would be 600 million shekels.
"One issue remains and we will continue to discuss it today in order to finalise it," Netanyahu said.

When asked whether the remaining issue was the policy of foreign exchange Netanyahu said: "Those are issues connected to a number of things, I prefer not to get into them now. We will continue discussing them today in order to finalise them."
